instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> HoT
threads.message:
Hello all.
I have finally found what I believe to be the problem with this macbook.

this is not my first post regarding this repair.

The macbook does not boot. 
main power rails are present.

<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> gets hot fast after it has mag plugged in. But no boot and no power.

has anyone got any recommendation as to what I can do about this.
The board originally had water damage around <RESISTOR>R1661</RESISTOR> the test point for <RESISTOR>R1661</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1663</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1669</RESISTOR> were completely corroded.

 <RESISTOR>R1663</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1662</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1664</RESISTOR> have been removed.
but I dont see how they could cause <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> to heat up so much.

any suggestions or advice is appreciated 
thanks

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> HoT
threads.message:
"no boot and no power"
You mean the board doesn't even try to start?

"main power rails are present"
Which ones, if you told no power???

Camera (<CHIP>U3900</CHIP>) is only powered up in S0 state. via <RESISTOR>R5421</RESISTOR>.
Will stay <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> cold if that resistor is removed?
It gets other voltages, but all in S0 state.
Please be clear in which sleep state stays your board.

However, <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is probably bad, it shouldn't go very hot nor even when is working.
You can rip it off and check if board starts.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> HoT
threads.message:
Ok thanks.
the board shows no sign of life asides from having the power rails in state s5 

I have put posts up about this board and gone through what rails are present.

I will remove that chip since it is not needed to run the machine. Thanks

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> HoT
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is not needed to start the board.
But you need to replace it, once the board will start working properly; unless you don't need the camera...

BTW, we will not search other thread about the same board, to see which voltages are present, or not.
Keep one thread open only, so we have all the info "at hand"...

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> HoT
threads.message:
Ok cool thanks.
and yes, sorry about that.
I'll test rails and report back asap.
thanks again
